header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: Article on World Peace Part 17

central_thesis: The article proposes a structured societal model where mandatory and voluntary work hours, assigned based on individual ability, ensure the community's self-sufficiency and foster social harmony, thereby contributing to the broader goal of 'World Peace' through collective responsibility and altruism.

structure_content.summary: This section outlines a social system for distributing labor within a self-sufficient community. It distinguishes between compulsory work hours, determined by individual strength and categorized into four tiers (1, 2, 4, or 8 hours per day), and voluntary work hours, contributed out of altruism. The system aims to meet all societal needs and establish social order where diligence is honored and negligence diminishes status, reflecting a 'Supreme Providence'.

key_concepts.definition: Compulsory work hours that each individual in a society must commit to, based on their self-assessed ability, to fulfill the community's collective needs.
Additional work hours contributed by individuals beyond their mandatory commitment, driven by a 'strong will to share with others' and contribute further to the community.

A tiered system for mandatory work: 'first kind' (weaklings) commit 1 hour/day; 'second kind' (healthy) commit 2 hours/day; 'third kind' (strong) commit 4 hours/day; 'fourth kind' (most energetic) commit 8 hours/day.
A group of people possessing sufficient means to cover all their needs, making them independent of external reliance, managed by an administration that allocates work hours.
Individuals who do not contribute diligently, resulting in a 'very low' social status because 'Supreme Providence has taken all honor away from them'.
Individuals who diligently contribute to society, thereby maintaining an 'obvious and apparent' higher status within the community.

practical_system.description: The practical system is a model for social organization centered on a collective work ethic. It mandates that each member of a self-sufficient society, in 'complete trustworthiness' and 'on his own accord,' assigns themselves to one of four compulsory work hour tiers (1, 2, 4, or 8 hours daily) based on their perceived ability. An administrative body is responsible for determining the total work hours required to meet all societal needs. Beyond mandatory contributions, all members are encouraged to offer voluntary work hours, driven by a desire to 'share with others.' The system implies that diligent participation ensures collective well-being and confers honor, while negligence results in social degradation, believed to be divinely ordained.

relevant_quotes.text: The status difference in the society between those who are negligent and those who are energetic is obvious and apparent: the status of those who are negligent in that society is very low because the Supreme Providence has taken all honor away from them.

Each society—that is, a number of people with means that are sufficient to cover all their needs and which makes them independent of others-has its own administration with an allotment of a certain number of work hours according to the conditions of their location.
There are four kinds of compulsory work hours that each person, in complete trustworthiness and on his own accord, must assign himself or herself to, in accordance with his ability:
These are the compulsory work hours, in addition to which there are members of all four kinds who are volunteering work hours out of their strong will to 'share with others'.

critical_analysis.relevance: This excerpt from Rav Ashlag's 'New Writings' is highly relevant within the context of Kabbalistic esotericism, particularly as it pertains to 'Tikkun Olam' (repair of the world) and the practical application of spiritual principles to societal structure. While not describing a ritualistic magic system, it outlines a form of 'social magic'—a blueprint for manifesting an ideal collective reality (World Peace, self-sufficiency, honor) through structured human action and ethical conduct. It posits that adherence to this system, based on altruism and individual responsibility, aligns human society with 'Supreme Providence,' thereby invoking divine blessings and order. This is a foundational, systemic approach to manifesting spiritual ideals in the material world, a common theme in practical Kabbalah which seeks to elevate physicality.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists of students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those interested in Rav Ashlag's teachings on social philosophy, collective spiritual elevation, and the practical implementation of Kabbalistic ethics into communal living. It would appeal to those seeking a deeper understanding of how spiritual principles can inform and structure a just and harmonious society, rather than those focused on personal ceremonial magic or grimoire traditions.
